Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Support for the INFOCOM 2014 Conference

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: The 2014 IEEE Conference on Computer Communications (INFOCOM) will be held in Toronto, Canada, April 27-May 2, 2014. This preeminent technical conference is the primary venue for presenting new research results in the area of computer communications, and is widely attended by researchers and practitioners in the field. Attending conferences such as INFOCOM is very important for the career development of graduate students. Participants have the opportunity to present their work, attend panel and keynote sessions, and interact with hundreds of others performing leading-edge research in the field. This proposal requests funding to support approximately 20 graduate students in the United States to attend this premier conference. Graduate students, in particular women and underrepresented minority students, will be supported, since attending conferences is an important part of their educational experience and they often have limited travel funds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2014 IEEE INFOCOM Conference on Computer Communications was held in Toronto, Canada from April 27 to May 2, 2014. This preeminent technical conference is the primary venue for presenting new research results in the area of computer communications, and is widely attended by researchers and practitioners in the field. The program consists of technical sessions, workshops, panels, and tutorials. The acceptance rate of Infocom 2014 was 19.4% (typically between 17% and 20% since 2004), which indicates the high quality of the conference. Due to the high volume of submissions from the US, the participation level from US participants was high. 

This project provided funding support to 25 graduate students in the United States to attend this premiere conference. The travel awards has targeted graduate students, in particular, women and underrepresented minority students, since attending conferences is an important part of their educational experience, and they often have limited travel funds. Paper authors have also been given priority in consideration. The awards were decided by the award selection committee consisting of four professors including two females.

Participants had the opportunity to present their work, attend panel and keynote sessions, and interact with hundreds of others performing leadingedge research in the field.
